study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether folic acid could modulate CLEC5A expression and inflammation in monocytes/macrophages, potentially impacting atherosclerosis progression.
results_summary: Folic acid increased DNMT1 expression, reduced CLEC5A expression, reversed high-fat-induced inflammation, and suppressed atherosclerotic plaque formation in vivo.
population_specificity: CAD patients and THP-1 cells (a monocyte cell line).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the rs1051266 variant of the SLC19A1 gene in ASD patients with cerebral folate deficiency (CFD) and assess its relationship with clinical and laboratory parameters, including folate metabolism markers.
results_summary: The study found significant correlations between homocysteine levels and vitamins B9, B12, and B6, as well as associations between specific genotypes (80GG) and elevated vitamin B12 levels in ASD and CFD patients. The rs1051266 variant was linked to modified clinical outcomes in ASD, highlighting variability in folate metabolism markers.
population_specificity: 227 children with autism spectrum disorders (ASD), 156 of whom had cerebral folate deficiency (CFD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether folic acid-functionalized nanoparticles could induce ferroptosis and pyroptosis in tumor cells by mobilizing endogenous iron and activating lysosome-intrinsic Fenton chemistry.
results_summary: The study found that UCNP-Cro/FA + NIR treatment effectively triggered lysosomal membrane permeabilization, leading to tumor cell death via ferroptosis and pyroptosis pathways, while also enhancing tumor immunogenicity.
population_specificity: Tumor cells (in vitro and in vivo models)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the effects and mechanisms by which folic acid regulates oxidative stress in bovine placental trophoblast cells to improve cows' reproductive performance.
results_summary: Folic acid increased cell proliferation, antioxidant enzyme expression, and total antioxidant capacity while reducing reactive oxygen species. It also upregulated tight junction factors, nutrient transporters, and the NRF2/mTOR signaling pathway, mitigating oxidative damage.
population_specificity: Bovine placental trophoblast cells (BPTCs)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the benefits of early comprehensive care, including folic acid supplementation, for newborns with sickle cell disease (SCD) in high-prevalence regions of India.
results_summary: The study protocol outlines a follow-up plan for SCD-affected newborns, including folic acid supplementation, but does not provide specific results on its efficacy. The abstract suggests that folic acid is part of a broader treatment strategy aimed at improving health outcomes.
population_specificity: Newborns with sickle cell disease (homozygous SS genotype) in high-prevalence regions of India.
study_duration: From six weeks up to five years of life

study_goal: The study aimed to explore the effect of genetic variants in MHC class I and II pathways on treatment outcomes in metastatic colorectal cancer patients, not specifically focused on Folic Acid (Vitamin B9).
results_summary: The study identified several SNPs in MHC pathway genes associated with treatment benefits in metastatic colorectal cancer patients, but did not report findings specific to Folic Acid (Vitamin B9).
population_specificity: Metastatic colorectal cancer patients enrolled in three randomized first-line trials (TRIBE, FIRE-3, MAVERICC).

study_goal: The study aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of nivolumab plus FOLFOX (NIVO+FOLFOX) in patients with advanced gastric cancer (AGC) and severe peritoneal metastasis.
results_summary: The study found that NIVO+FOLFOX was feasible for AGC patients with severe peritoneal metastasis, showing potential for long-term survival and ascites reduction, with 20.0% achieving disease control beyond 1 year and 30.7% achieving complete ascites resolution.
population_specificity: Patients with advanced gastric cancer (AGC) and severe peritoneal metastasis (massive ascites and/or inadequate oral intake).
effective_dosage: Not specified for Folic Acid (Vitamin B9).
study_duration: The study period was from January 2022 to December 2023, but the exact duration of intervention per patient is not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to highlight the potential role of early antenatal folic acid supplementation in preventing congenital anomalies like femoral-facial syndrome.
results_summary: The study suggests that lack of antenatal folic acid supplementation may have contributed to severe congenital anomalies in the infant, implying that early supplementation could have averted the condition.
population_specificity: A preterm Black Bantu African female infant with femoral-facial syndrome and a mother who did not receive antenatal folic acid.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of folic acid (FA)-conjugated nanoparticles for targeted drug delivery of doxorubicin (DOX) to cancer cells overexpressing folate receptors.
results_summary: FA-conjugated nanoparticles enhanced intracellular uptake and DOX accumulation in the nucleus, leading to significantly higher cytotoxicity in U87 cancer cells compared to non-FA-conjugated nanoparticles. The FA-DOX-MOC NPs showed pH-dependent drug release, with faster release in acidic conditions.
population_specificity: U87 cancer cells (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of folic acid administration on mortality and complication incidences in poisoned patients.
results_summary: Folic acid administration significantly improved mortality and complication incidences (p < 0.05), though its therapeutic efficiency was deemed questionable.
population_specificity: Poisoned patients treated at an Egyptian tertiary poison control center.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of folic acid supplementation in preconception care for women with pre-existing diabetes to prevent congenital abnormalities.
results_summary: The study found that folic acid supplementation is critically required prior to conception in women with pre-existing diabetes to reduce the risk of congenital abnormalities, alongside stringent blood glucose control.
population_specificity: Women with pre-existing diabetes or gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify the potential role of Folic Acid (Vitamin B9) as an active component in Boletus edulis for alleviating muscle atrophy, focusing on its molecular mechanisms and efficacy.
results_summary: Folic Acid was identified as one of the active components in Boletus edulis with potential to treat or alleviate muscle atrophy, though the primary focus of the study was on Sesamin and the PI3K/AKT signaling pathway. The study did not isolate Folic Acid's effects but included it among the promising compounds.
population_specificity: Mice and C2C12 skeletal muscle cells (in vitro).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the cost-effectiveness of FOLFOXIRI/FOLFOXIRI compared with mFOLFOX6/FOLFIRI in treating metastatic colorectal cancer (mCRC) from the perspectives of the USA and China.
results_summary: The study found that FOLFOXIRI/FOLFOXIRI improved health outcomes more efficiently than mFOLFOX6/FOLFIRI, with incremental cost-effectiveness ratios below willingness-to-pay thresholds in both the USA and China. The regimen showed higher probabilities of being cost-effective, particularly in the USA (99.6%).
population_specificity: Patients with histologically confirmed metastatic colorectal adenocarcinoma.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of folic acid as part of a treatment regimen for actinomycetoma, alongside trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole and amoxicillin-clavulanic acid.
results_summary: Folic acid was used as part of a successful treatment protocol for actinomycetoma, contributing to positive outcomes in three reported cases. The study did not isolate folic acid's individual effects but noted its inclusion in the Cochrane systemic review protocol 2018.
population_specificity: Patients with actinomycetoma (three cases reported).

study_goal: The researchers assessed the practice patterns of medical oncologists in Canada regarding the use of FOLFIRINOX (FFX) chemotherapy for advanced pancreatic cancer, including dosing and toxicity management.
results_summary: The study found that FFX was prescribed non-uniformly, with frequent dose reductions (78.1%) and delays (65.2%). Standard-dose FFX was used only 31% of the time, and GCSF was prescribed for primary prophylaxis in 30% of standard-dose cases.
population_specificity: Patients with advanced pancreatic cancer (median age 61, 43% female, 96% ECOG PS 0-1, 50% with ≥3 metastatic sites) treated at eight Canadian cancer centers.
effective_dosage: Not specified for Folic Acid (Vitamin B9)
study_duration: Median follow-up time was 20.8 months (95% CI 18.6-24.9)

study_goal: The study aimed to evaluate the feasibility and effectiveness of adjuvant chemotherapy (mFOLFOX6, which includes leucovorin, a form of folic acid) after lung metastasectomy for colorectal cancer.
results_summary: The study found a 5-year overall survival rate of 85.2% and a 5-year disease-free survival rate of 60.2% with mFOLFOX6, suggesting potential efficacy. Adverse events included neutropenia (50.0%), fatigue (7.7%), and peripheral sensory neuropathy (7.7%).
population_specificity: Patients with colorectal adenocarcinoma who underwent first curative resection of ≤4 lung metastases and had no prior chemotherapy.
effective_dosage: Not specified for folic acid (leucovorin) alone; mFOLFOX6 regimen included 12 cycles.
study_duration: 12 cycles of mFOLFOX6 (exact duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of folic acid-modified β-cyclodextrin grafted polyethyleneimine (β-CD-PEI-FA) nanocomposites for delivering miR-34a-5p in anti-KSHV therapy.
results_summary: The study demonstrated that the folic acid-modified nanocomposites exhibited exceptional biocompatibility and effectively delivered miR-34a-5p into KSHV-positive cells, inhibiting their proliferation and reducing pathogenic gene expression. The nanocomposites also successfully penetrated brain tissues, including tumors, in vivo.
population_specificity: In vitro and in vivo models, including xenograft mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) reduce the efficacy of adjuvant UFT/LV therapy in stage II/III colorectal cancer patients by lowering active folic acid levels.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in relapse-free survival between PPI and non-PPI groups, suggesting PPIs do not reduce the efficacy of UFT/LV therapy. The 5-year RFS rates were similar (73.8% vs. 77.1%).
population_specificity: Patients with stage II/III colorectal cancer who underwent curative surgery and received adjuvant UFT/LV therapy.
interactions: Proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) were examined for potential interaction with UFT/LV therapy.

study_goal: The study aimed to investigate the role of liquid biopsy-comprehensive genomic profiling (LBx-CGP) in predicting the efficacy of anti-EGFR therapies in RAS/BRAF wild-type metastatic colorectal cancer (mCRC).
results_summary: The study found that patients with negatively hyper-selected tumors (no mutations in potential anti-EGFR resistance genes) had a higher overall response rate (78.1%) and longer progression-free survival (12.35 months) compared to patients with mutations. LBx-CGP helped identify acquired resistance mutations and optimize anti-EGFR therapy continuation.
population_specificity: RAS/BRAF wild-type microsatellite stable metastatic colorectal cancer patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of FOLFIRINOX (which includes Folinic acid, a derivative of Folic Acid) in achieving long-term disease control in a rare case of pancreatic carcinosarcoma.
results_summary: FOLFIRINOX initially showed a partial response to liver metastases, followed by a long-term complete radiological response, suggesting efficacy in palliative treatment for this rare cancer. The study highlights the potential of this regimen for disease control but does not isolate the specific role of Folic Acid.
population_specificity: A woman in her 60s with pancreatic carcinosarcoma, BRCA1 mutation, and prior triple-negative breast cancer.
effective_dosage: Not specified (FOLFIRINOX regimen includes Folinic acid, but exact dosage not detailed).
study_duration: Continued until long-term complete radiological response (exact duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether folic acid-modified liposomes could effectively target M1-polarized macrophages to reduce inflammation and slow osteoarthritis progression.
results_summary: The study found that folic acid-modified liposomes successfully targeted M1 macrophages, reduced ROS levels, shifted macrophage polarization, and alleviated inflammation and cartilage damage in both lab and animal models.
population_specificity: Mouse model with osteoarthritis induced by anterior cruciate ligament transection (ACLT).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of folic acid-conjugated Nintedanib-loaded solid lipid nanoparticles (FA-NIN-SLNPs) for targeted lung cancer therapy.
results_summary: FA-NIN-SLNPs demonstrated enhanced apoptosis (86.65%) in A549 lung cancer cells compared to non-targeted nanoparticles (67.65%) and free drug (23.53%), with improved lung-specific accumulation and a favorable safety profile in histopathological and hemolysis assessments.
population_specificity: A549 lung cancer cells (in vitro) and likely animal models (in vivo, inferred from pharmacokinetic and biodistribution studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a folic acid-conjugated iron-based MOF loaded with 1,8-acridinediones for targeted photodynamic therapy in HepG-2 cells.
results_summary: The nanocomposite demonstrated high stability in physiological conditions and targeted release in acidic tumor environments, showing significant efficacy in inhibiting HepG-2 cell growth under light conditions, primarily through necrosis due to ROS generation.
population_specificity: HepG-2 cells (a human liver cancer cell line).
effective_dosage: IC50 values of 8.94 and 11.78 μg mL-1 under light conditions for 50% and 30% DO8-loaded MOF-FA, respectively.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of a five-step forest bathing protocol on reducing mental distress (anxiety, depression, and stress) in undergraduate students.
results_summary: The forest bathing protocol significantly reduced anxiety (48.4%), depression (35.4%), and stress (33.5%) in participants, with greater effects observed in parks with higher naturalness. The findings support the integration of nature-based solutions in university settings to enhance student mental wellbeing.
population_specificity: Thirty-six newly enrolled university students in São José dos Campos, São Paulo, Brazil.
effective_dosage: Three nature-based sessions spaced approximately one month apart.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if forest bathing improves adolescents' mental well-being and to understand participants' experiences of the practice.
results_summary: The study found a significant increase in mental well-being after forest bathing, with moderate to large effect sizes, and participants reported reduced stress and increased relaxation, peace, and happiness.
population_specificity: Adolescents aged 16-18
effective_dosage: Three forest bathing sessions over 3 weeks

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of forest bathing on mental health, including its potential to alleviate depression, anxiety, and stress, and to identify factors influencing its effectiveness.
results_summary: Forest bathing interventions improved mental and physical health, reduced blood pressure, enhanced sleep quality, boosted immunity, and alleviated depression, anxiety, and stress. The effects varied based on forest environment, tree species, exposure duration, season, and volatile organic compounds.
population_specificity: General population, with variations noted among different groups.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the physiological effects of forest bathing on stress management, focusing on changes in stress-related biomarkers and perceived stress levels.
results_summary: Forest bathing significantly reduced salivary cortisol and electrodermal activity, increased heart rate variability, and improved parasympathetic activity during stress tasks, indicating enhanced stress management. However, diastolic blood pressure unexpectedly rose post-exposure.
population_specificity: 29 volunteers (specific demographics not detailed).
effective_dosage: 2 days of full immersion in a forest environment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effect of forest bathing on depression in female participants with depression/depressive tendencies, comparing it to city walking.
results_summary: Forest bathing significantly reduced depression scores (SDS), increased blood serotonin (in non-antidepressant users), oxytocin, and IGF-1 levels, improved mood (POMS test), reduced fatigue, and enhanced sleep quality compared to city walking. Effects lasted for one week post-intervention.
population_specificity: 31 females aged 40.1 ± 2.4 years with depression/depressive tendencies.
effective_dosage: Two 2.5 km walks (90 min each, totaling 5.0 km/day) in a forest park.
study_duration: Two-day intervention (forest and city walking on separate days).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify programmatic components, health outcomes, geographical trends, and themes in shinrin-yoku (forest bathing) research worldwide.
results_summary: The study found that forest bathing has physiological and psychological benefits across age groups, with significant health benefits observed in both natural and virtual environments. Continued research is encouraged to explore short- and long-term health outcomes.
population_specificity: Across age groups (not further specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to critically analyze the evidence on Shinrin-Yoku's efficacy for treating depression and explore its relevance to osteopathic principles and practice.
results_summary: The review found Shinrin-Yoku improved self-reported mood scores and induced physiological changes, but the evidence was methodologically weak and lacked generalizability. Suggestions were made for improving future research.
population_specificity: Individuals with depression (specific demographics not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether an urban nature connection intervention (ParkBathe) could improve adolescents' nature connection and wellbeing.
results_summary: The study found statistically significant improvements in anxiety (13% reduction), rumination (44% reduction), scepticism (17% reduction), nature connection (25% increase), and social connection (12% increase), with the largest effect size for nature connection. Participants reported immediate calming and relaxing effects from the intervention.
population_specificity: Adolescents sampled opportunistically from Scouts groups.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of forest-bathing alongside physical rehabilitation and nutrition in aiding the recovery of bedridden patients.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that combining physiotherapy, proper nutrition, and nature-based therapies like forest-bathing may help in the recovery of physically inactive patients, though specific outcomes for forest-bathing alone are not detailed.
population_specificity: Bedridden patients with prolonged inactivity due to age-related muscle loss, trauma, surgery, cancer, or severe pathologies.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the preliminary efficacy and feasibility of a forest bathing intervention for adults with intellectual disabilities, focusing on physiological and psychological outcomes.
results_summary: The study proposes an 11-week forest bathing program to evaluate effects on blood pressure, psycho-physiological coherence, and quality of life, while also assessing feasibility through implementation barriers and environmental comfort indicators.
population_specificity: Adults with intellectual disabilities

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a three-hour, guided Shinrin-Yoku (Forest Bathing) intervention could reduce burnout symptoms among physicians and other healthcare workers.
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant differences in burnout scores between the intervention and control groups, but participants reported subjective improvements in stress and mental wellbeing after the Forest Bathing walk.
population_specificity: Physicians and other healthcare workers

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the feasibility and effectiveness of online forest bathing in improving well-being and symptom severity in adults with Long-COVID.
results_summary: Online forest bathing led to statistically significant improvements in anxiety (49% decrease), rumination (48% decrease), social connection (78% increase), and Long-COVID symptoms (22% decrease), with qualitative feedback highlighting feelings of calm, joy, and social and nature-connectedness.
population_specificity: Adults with Long-COVID (n=22).
effective_dosage: Four weekly online forest bathing sessions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the effects of physical exercise and forest bathing on immune system strengthening, particularly in relation to COVID-19 prevention and severity reduction.
results_summary: The study found that physical activity in forested areas may enhance immune defenses due to inhalation of biogenic volatile compounds (VOCs), which have immunostimulatory effects. Forest bathing also helps reduce stress and anxiety, supporting immune function.
population_specificity: General population, with implications for COVID-19 prevention.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the health effects of forest bathing, specifically its impact on blood pressure and immune cell activity, comparing outcomes between the green season and winter.
results_summary: Forest bathing reduced systolic blood pressure in both seasons and stimulated immune cell activity, particularly NKbright cells in the green season, while showing a slight activating and balancing effect on TIM-3 expression in winter.
population_specificity: Twelve healthy, working-age volunteers.
study_duration: Single sessions in May (green season) and January (winter).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to discuss the limitations of current shinrin-yoku research and propose future research directions to evaluate its effects on addiction.
results_summary: The abstract does not report specific findings but highlights the global attention shinrin-yoku has received and its clinical use in Japan since 1982.
population_specificity: Not specified in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the physiological and psychological effects of forest bathing on working-age individuals with and without depressive tendencies.
results_summary: Forest bathing significantly reduced systolic and diastolic blood pressure and improved mood states, particularly in participants with depressive tendencies, who showed greater improvements in negative mood states compared to those without depressive tendencies.
population_specificity: Working-age individuals (155 participants) with and without depressive tendencies (excluding severely depressed individuals).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the therapeutic benefits of forest bathing for adults with pre-hypertension or hypertension and identify effective intervention types, durations, and frequencies.
results_summary: Forest bathing reduced blood pressure, pulse rate, and anxiety while improving heart rate variability, cardiac-pulmonary function, metabolic function, mood, and quality of life. Forest walking and therapy programs were the most effective interventions.
population_specificity: Middle-aged and elderly adults with pre-hypertension or hypertension.
effective_dosage: Single sessions of forest walking or therapy programs (specific frequency not detailed).
study_duration: Short-term benefits observed (exact duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review recent literature on the physiological and psychological benefits of forest bathing, specifically its effects on heart rate variability (InHF) and anxiety reduction.
results_summary: The study found that forest bathing increases InHF, indicating parasympathetic nervous system activation, and reduces anxiety. These effects were supported by recent literature.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of existing literature).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether forest bathing reduces stress by measuring its effects on salivary or serum cortisol levels.
results_summary: The meta-analysis showed significantly lower cortisol levels in forest groups compared to urban groups, both before and after intervention, indicating stress reduction. Most studies reported significant pre-post reductions in cortisol levels in forest groups.
population_specificity: Not specified (general population implied)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether forest bathing could serve as a beneficial adjunctive therapy for elderly patients with chronic heart failure (CHF).
results_summary: Forest bathing significantly reduced brain natriuretic peptide (BNP), cardiovascular disease-related pathological factors, inflammatory cytokines, and improved antioxidant function and mood states compared to urban environments.
population_specificity: Elderly patients with chronic heart failure (CHF).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review empirical studies on the physiological and psychological effects of Shinrin-Yoku (Forest Bathing) in Japan and China and encourage further longitudinal research in Western cultures.
results_summary: The review found significant health benefits associated with Forest Bathing, including physiological and psychological improvements, and suggested its potential as a universal health model for reducing stress and technostress.
population_specificity: Various populations in diverse settings (not further specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to provide scientific evidence supporting forest bathing as a natural therapy for hypertension by examining its effects on blood pressure, cardiovascular biomarkers, and mood states.
results_summary: Forest bathing significantly reduced blood pressure and improved cardiovascular biomarkers compared to urban exposure, while also lowering negative mood scores. Air quality in the forest was superior to the urban area, with higher negative ion levels and lower PM10.
population_specificity: Elderly patients with essential hypertension (n=24).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the pain-reducing effects of forest bathing alone versus forest bathing combined with stretching and strengthening exercises in patients with chronic posterior neck pain.
results_summary: Forest bathing with exercise (FBE) significantly reduced the number of trigger points (TRPs) compared to forest bathing alone (FBA), but no significant differences were found in other pain measurement scales between the two groups.
population_specificity: 64 subjects with chronic posterior neck pain lasting more than 3 months.
effective_dosage: 2 hours of forest walking daily for 5 days; FBE group additionally performed 4 hours of stretching and strengthening exercises in the afternoon.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the physiological and psychological benefits of forest bathing compared to urban environments using biological indicators.
results_summary: Forest bathing significantly increased parasympathetic nervous activity, reduced salivary cortisol and pulse rate, and improved psychological well-being compared to urban settings. The study demonstrated clear positive physiological and psychological outcomes in forest environments.
population_specificity: Young Japanese male adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify novel KHK-C inhibitors with improved pharmacokinetics, efficacy, and safety profiles to treat fructose-driven metabolic disorders.
results_summary: Ten compounds showed superior binding affinity and free energy compared to clinical candidates PF-06835919 and LY-3522348, with compound 2 emerging as the most stable and promising KHK-C inhibitor. The study suggests compound 2 has potential for treating metabolic disorders linked to excessive fructose consumption.
population_specificity: Computational screening (no human or animal subjects specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether S-nitrosylation proteins, particularly fructose-1,6-bisphosphate aldolase 2 (FBA2), play a role in regulating energy metabolism in mini Chinese cabbage seedlings under low-temperature stress.
results_summary: Low temperature inhibited energy metabolism-related gene transcription, but exogenous BR and S-nitrosoglutathione upregulated these genes and increased ATP release. BR enhanced FBA2 S-nitrosylation, aiding energy homeostasis in seedlings.
population_specificity: Mini Chinese cabbage seedlings

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects and underlying mechanisms of fructose on bone health, specifically its role in exacerbating bone loss and potential therapeutic targets for osteoporosis.
results_summary: Fructose intake worsened bone loss in mice by increasing cholesterol accumulation in bones, reducing bone density, and impairing osteogenic differentiation of BMSCs. Targeting Thrb activation and Prkcz inhibition significantly improved bone loss.
population_specificity: Murine models (mice)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the impact of fructose metabolism in the central nervous system on energy metabolism and glucose homeostasis, specifically focusing on leptin receptor-expressing neurons.
results_summary: The study found no significant changes in body weight, blood glucose, or fructose preference in KhkΔLepR mice under normal conditions or after long-term fructose consumption, suggesting KHK-mediated fructose metabolism in these neurons is not essential for fructose preference or energy homeostasis.
population_specificity: Leptin receptor cell-specific Khk knockout mice (LepR-Cre;Khkfl/fl, KhkΔLepR)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the relationship between metabolic health, short-term fructose restriction, and changes in leukocyte telomere length (LTL) in children.
results_summary: Higher baseline HDL-C and APO-AI levels were associated with reduced LTL attrition, while increases in APO-AI over the study period correlated with increased LTL attrition. The study found no association between LTL changes and non-HDL-C lipids.
population_specificity: 43 Black and Latinx children

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the prognostic utility of fructose (levulose) as an early liver function test in comparison to other biomarkers and established criteria like KCC and MELD.
results_summary: The abstract mentions fructose as one of the earliest liver function tests but does not provide specific results on its efficacy or performance compared to other biomarkers. It concludes that no single biomarker, including fructose, clearly outperforms existing tools like KCC or MELD.
population_specificity: Patients with acute liver failure (ALF).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of a high-fat high-fructose diet (HFHFD) on obesity-related metabolic and neurodegenerative changes in rats and assess the efficacy of a combined multitarget therapy (OLHHA+LIG) in reversing these alterations.
results_summary: The HFHFD induced weight gain, elevated plasma triglycerides and LDL, disrupted brain protein expression related to food intake and neurodegeneration, and altered tau phosphorylation. Combined treatment (OLHHA+LIG) was more effective than individual treatments in reversing these effects.
population_specificity: Rats fed a high-fat high-fructose diet (HFHFD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether mannose supplementation could mitigate liver steatosis and fibrosis by targeting fructose metabolism, specifically through ketohexokinase inhibition.
results_summary: Mannose reduced liver steatosis and fibrosis in murine models and human liver slices by decreasing ketohexokinase expression, with its effects dependent on fructose presence.
population_specificity: Murine models (fat-and-tumor MASH, CCl4-induced fibrosis) and human precision-cut liver slices from end-stage MASH cirrhosis patients.
study_duration: 12 weeks (Prevention group: entire duration; Therapy group: weeks 6-12).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether serum fructose levels influence pregnancy outcomes (miscarriage in PCOS patients and preterm delivery in non-PCOS patients).
results_summary: Higher serum fructose levels were significantly associated with increased miscarriage risk in PCOS patients and preterm delivery in non-PCOS patients, with strong statistical correlations and predictive accuracy (AUC 0.686 for PCOS, 0.731 for non-PCOS).
population_specificity: 270 women (135 with PCOS, 135 without PCOS) undergoing IVF-ET treatment at a reproductive medicine center in China.
effective_dosage: Not specified (serum levels measured, not administered).
study_duration: Pregnancy monitoring until outcome determination (exact duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether high fructose corn syrup (HFCS) consumption impairs nerve healing and functional recovery following sciatic nerve injury in mice.
results_summary: HFCS consumption impaired mechanical and thermal sensory functions and resulted in poor nerve repair. Ivermectin improved sensory and motor function recovery in HFCS-consuming mice and ameliorated insulin resistance.
population_specificity: Male Swiss albino mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand the role of FBP1 in cancer progression and whether targeting FBP1 could be a potential therapeutic approach.
results_summary: The study found that FBP1 deficiency is linked to cancer resistance to therapy and poor prognosis, and restoring FBP1 expression may hold promise for cancer treatment. FBP1 also influences gene transcription, mRNA regulation, and the tumor immune microenvironment.
population_specificity: Cancer patients and tumor microenvironments.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the hypoglycemic properties and gut microbiota modulation of fermented mulberries (FM) after removing fructose and glucose.
results_summary: FM administration in type 2 diabetic mice reduced blood sugar and insulin levels, improved dyslipidemia and insulin resistance, enhanced antioxidant capacity, repaired organ damage, and regulated gut microbiota by increasing beneficial bacteria and inhibiting harmful ones.
population_specificity: Type 2 diabetic mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of high-fructose diets on metabolic and oxidative stress parameters in obese rats and assess whether trans-resveratrol (RSV) could ameliorate these effects.
results_summary: High-fructose diets (HF and HF/HFAT) significantly increased body weight, glycemic parameters, lipid levels, and oxidative stress markers while downregulating key metabolic genes (SIRT-1, PGC-1α, Cyto-c, GLUT-4). RSV supplementation restored metabolic and oxidative stress alterations and upregulated these genes.
population_specificity: Obese male Wistar rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether morroniside could inhibit the progression of chronic kidney disease (CKD) caused by high-fat and high-fructose diets in mice.
results_summary: The study found that high-fat and high-fructose diets induced renal lipotoxicity and CKD progression in mice, which was significantly improved by morroniside treatment. Morroniside promoted lipophagy and inhibited NLRP3 inflammasome activation via AMPK/TFEB signaling.
population_specificity: High-fat and high-fructose-fed mice and palmitic acid-induced HK-2 cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether honokiol (Hon) could mitigate fructose-induced small intestinal permeability and early metabolic dysfunction-associated steatotic liver disease (MASLD).
results_summary: Honokiol reduced fructose-induced liver damage (lower NAS, neutrophils, and IL-6) and improved intestinal barrier function (lower bacterial toxin, higher tight junction proteins, reduced NOx). These effects were supported by in vivo, ex vivo, and Caco-2 cell models.
population_specificity: Female C57BL/6J mice (8-10 weeks old).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of Stevioside-modified selenium nanoparticles (SV-SeNPs) on high fructose-palmitate (HFP)-induced lipid accumulation in HepG2 cells.
results_summary: SV-SeNPs significantly inhibited lipid accumulation by suppressing key lipogenesis genes (FASN, ACC1, SCD1) and activating the PI3K/AKT/Nrf2 pathway. They also reduced oxidative stress by upregulating antioxidant enzymes (SOD, GSHPx).
population_specificity: HepG2 cells (a human liver cell line)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of fructose-induced metabolic syndrome on bladder dysfunction and whether tadalafil could mitigate these effects.
results_summary: Fructose-fed rats exhibited metabolic syndrome-associated bladder overactivity and chronic ischemia, which were alleviated by tadalafil treatment through improved angiogenesis and reduced inflammation and oxidative stress.
population_specificity: Fructose-fed rats (a model of metabolic syndrome).
effective_dosage: Not specified for fructose (tadalafil dosage was 2 mg/kg).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of a high-fat-high-fructose diet (HFFD) on heart function in hereditary hypertriacylglycerolemic (HTG) rats as a model for metabolic syndrome and depression.
results_summary: The study found that HFFD led to electrical abnormalities in the heart (prolonged QRS complex, increased heart rate) and reduced contractile function (lower LVDP). Venlafaxine partially mitigated some cardiac effects, such as shortening the QT interval after ischemia/reperfusion injury.
population_specificity: Male hereditary hypertriacylglycerolemic (HTG) rats.
effective_dosage: Not specified (high-fat-high-fructose diet composition not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of Fructose 1,6-bisphosphatase 1 (FBP1) as a prognostic biomarker in glioblastoma (GBM) and its underlying mechanisms affecting tumor progression.
results_summary: High FBP1 expression correlated with worse GBM prognosis. Silencing FBP1 suppressed GBM cell proliferation, invasion, migration, and aerobic glycolysis while modulating PI3K/AKT pathway activity and macrophage M2 polarization.
population_specificity: Glioblastoma (GBM) cells and normal glial cell line HEB.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify α-Mangostin analogs with improved inhibitory properties against KHK-C to address fructose-driven metabolic disorders.
results_summary: Sixteen analogs showed superior binding affinities compared to α-Mangostin, with hit 8 emerging as the most promising due to its high binding affinity, favorable pharmacokinetics, and stable interactions with KHK-C. These findings suggest potential for treating fructose-driven metabolic disorders.
population_specificity: Not specified (in silico study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the harmful effects of a high-fructose diet in inducing non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) and evaluate resveratrol's therapeutic potential in mitigating these effects.
results_summary: A high-fructose diet induced NASH in rats, causing biochemical and histopathological abnormalities, while resveratrol treatment improved liver health by enhancing autophagy, reducing inflammation, and restoring oxidative balance via the AMPK/Nrf2 pathway.
population_specificity: Male albino rats
effective_dosage: 70% fructose diet for six weeks (NASH induction); 70 mg/kg resveratrol daily for six weeks (treatment)
study_duration: Six weeks for fructose diet induction, followed by six weeks of resveratrol treatment

study_goal: The researchers were attempting to determine the effects of EGFR inhibitors (lapatinib and PD153035) on liver fat accumulation, particularly in the context of fatty liver.
results_summary: Short-term treatment with EGFR inhibitors reduced liver fat accumulation, but long-term treatment showed no significant difference in lipid accumulation compared to the model group, leading to the retraction of the study.
population_specificity: Not specified (likely animal or in vitro model based on context).
study_duration: Not specified (short-term and long-term treatments mentioned but durations not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the damaging effects of fructose on immune function, particularly glycation of IgG proteins, and assess the protective potential of an antioxidant mixture.
results_summary: Fructose significantly compromised immune function by damaging key proteins, but the antioxidant mixture (glutathione, oleuropein, selenium) effectively mitigated this damage, offering protection against glycation.
population_specificity: Human IgG proteins glycated in vitro and lymphocyte cells from healthy volunteers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of a high-fat, high-fructose diet (HFFD) on offspring and the potential protective role of ferulic acid (FA) against developmental and metabolic abnormalities.
results_summary: Maternal HFFD increased offspring's blood glucose, insulin resistance, lipid levels, and caused organ developmental retardations. FA treatment mitigated these adverse effects, maintaining normoglycemia, healthy lipid profiles, and preventing developmental issues.
population_specificity: Female rats and their offspring.
study_duration: 9 weeks prior to and throughout gestation and lactation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess quercetin's protective effects against fructose-induced hepatic steatosis in mice.
results_summary: Quercetin significantly reduced liver fat percentages, inflammation, and steatosis in mice on a high fructose diet, with higher doses showing more pronounced effects. It also improved gut microbiota composition and metabolic parameters.
population_specificity: Male C57BL/6J mice
effective_dosage: 50 mg/kg (low dose) and 100 mg/kg (high dose) quercetin

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the impact of high fructose on cardiomyocyte proliferation in neonatal mice and primary rat cardiomyocytes.
results_summary: High fructose inhibited cardiomyocyte proliferation in vivo and in vitro, likely by suppressing the Notch1 signaling pathway. The study linked high fructose consumption to adverse cardiac effects, including inhibited proliferation and potential heart damage.
population_specificity: Neonatal ICR mice and primary rat cardiomyocytes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether fructose and galactose ingestion elevates lactate concentrations in patients with glycogen storage disease type 1 (GSD1).
results_summary: Fructose ingestion led to increased lactate levels in some patients, with varying peak times and magnitudes, while others showed no change or a decrease. The effects were inconsistent across patients and consumption methods (milk, juice, or water).
population_specificity: 7 patients with GSD1 (6 with GSD1a and 1 with GSD1b).
effective_dosage: 200 mL of juice (fructose source) or milk (galactose source), single dose.

study_goal: The researchers compared the tumor uptake efficiency and intratumoral accumulation of PEG400-BPA versus fructose-BPA in Boron Neutron Capture Therapy (BNCT).
results_summary: PEG400-BPA showed nearly twice the boron uptake in tumor cells compared to fructose-BPA and exhibited a better tumor-to-normal tissue ratio (T/N). Fructose-BPA was used as a clinical benchmark but demonstrated lower efficacy in these metrics.
population_specificity: GL261 cells (in vitro) and unspecified in vivo models (likely animal studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the antihyperglycemic and antihyperlipidemic effects of fenugreek seed extract on fructose-induced diabetic Wistar rats.
results_summary: Fenugreek seed extract significantly improved fasting blood sugar, total cholesterol, and triglyceride levels in diabetic rats, while also increasing food and water consumption and body weight compared to controls.
population_specificity: Fructose-induced diabetic Wistar rats.
effective_dosage: 500 mg/kg of fenugreek seed extract, administered consecutively for 28 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the relationship between acute heat stress (HS), endogenous fructose production, and kidney injury.
results_summary: The study found that acute HS increases reactive oxygen species, activating Nrf-2 and Akr1b3, leading to elevated endogenous fructose levels in kidney cells, which contributes to kidney damage. Inhibiting Nrf-2 reduced fructose levels and mitigated kidney injury.
population_specificity: Kidney cells (in vitro or animal model, not specified for humans).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of 6-G on reducing ER stress-induced NAFLD in metabolic syndrome rats fed a high-fat high-fructose diet.
results_summary: The study found that 6-G treatment reduced ER stress markers (GRP78, IRE1, TRAF2, p-JNK, p-NF-κB), liver apoptosis, and NAS scores in NAFLD rats, while also lowering ALT, AST, and ALP serum levels.
population_specificity: Male Sprague-Dawley rats with metabolic syndrome induced by a high-fat high-fructose diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of a high-fructose diet (HFrD) on metabolic and vascular dysfunction in the context of allergic asthma and evaluate rosuvastatin's potential modulatory effects.
results_summary: HFrD led to significant increases in body weight, abdominal circumference, lipid profiles, and blood glucose, worsened by allergic asthma. Rosuvastatin reduced lipid levels, inflammation markers, and improved vascular function while mitigating tissue thickening.
population_specificity: Sprague-Dawley rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify microRNA profiles and RNA regulatory networks involved in NAFLD development induced by a high-fructose diet in mice.
results_summary: The study identified 13 differentially expressed miRNAs and 854 differentially expressed genes in the livers of mice fed a high-fructose diet, with the miR-22-5p/Clec4e axis emerging as a potential diagnostic target for NAFLD.
population_specificity: Mice (animal model)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Lycium ruthenicum Murray extract (LRE) could mitigate cognitive dysfunction and neuroinflammation induced by a high-fat and high-fructose diet (HFFD) in mice.
results_summary: LRE attenuated HFFD-induced neuroinflammation, improved cognitive deficits, modulated gut microbiota, and enhanced neuroprotective bile acid synthesis. It reduced pro-inflammatory cytokines (TNF-α, IL-6, IL-1β) and altered microbial populations (increased Streptococcus/Lactococcus, decreased Helicobacter/Clostridium_XIVa).
population_specificity: Mice fed a high-fat and high-fructose diet.

study_goal: The study aimed to investigate the effects of ghrelin on DNA repair, apoptosis mechanisms, oxidative stress, and pancreatic hormone levels in diabetic rats, not fructose.
results_summary: The study found that ghrelin reduced oxidative stress and apoptosis markers (caspase-3 and caspase-9) in diabetic rats, suggesting potential therapeutic benefits for type 2 diabetes. No results related to fructose were reported.
population_specificity: Diabetic rats (type 2 diabetes mellitus model)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of Lactarius volemus Fr. polysaccharides (LVP) on metabolic disorders and intestinal barrier dysfunction in high-fat, high-fructose diet (HFFD)-induced obese mice.
results_summary: LVP supplementation significantly improved hyperlipoidemia, hyperglycemia, insulin resistance, hepatic inflammation, and steatosis. It also enhanced intestinal barrier function and microbiota composition, likely through regulation of hepatic insulin signaling and suppression of MAPKs pathways.
population_specificity: HFFD-induced obese mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of a high-fat/high-fructose (HFF) diet combined with O. viverrini infection on metabolic dysfunction-associated steatotic liver disease (MASLD).
results_summary: The study found that the HFF diet, especially when combined with O. viverrini infection, led to significant hepatic damage, including lipid-droplet accumulation, inflammation, fibrosis, and metabolic dysfunction. Biochemical and histopathological analyses confirmed worsened liver function and increased expression of fibrotic and inflammatory markers in the HFF+OV group.
population_specificity: Male golden hamsters (animal study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of fructose, as an end-product of the polyol pathway, in promoting cancer cell survival and chemotherapy resistance in NSCLC.
results_summary: The study found that fructose and other non-glycolytic hexoses support cancer cell survival and confer chemotherapy resistance via sustained NF-κB activity and metabolic oxidative switching. PP pathway interference was proposed as a potential therapeutic strategy against NSCLC.
population_specificity: Non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) cells in vitro and murine xenograft models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how reactive oxygen species (ROS) reduce nitric oxide (NO) and impact neuroinflammation in the nucleus tractus solitarius (NTS) of fructose-induced hypertensive rats.
results_summary: Fructose intake increased blood pressure and reduced NO due to oxidative stress and neuroinflammation. CLI-095 and glycyrrhizic acid (GA) treatments reduced blood pressure, preserved NO synthase availability, and decreased inflammation by inhibiting acetylated HMGB1-TLR4 interaction.
population_specificity: Male Wistar-Kyoto (WKY) rats
effective_dosage: 10% fructose water; CLI-095 and GA at 1 mg·12 μL-1·day-1 (intracerebroventricular injection)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of a high-fructose diet on female reproductive health and assess metformin's potential to mitigate these effects.
results_summary: A high-fructose diet caused metabolic disturbances, ovarian dysfunction, uterine inflammation, and vaginal dysbiosis, while metformin improved ovarian impairments and vaginal microbiota.
population_specificity: Wistar albino rats
effective_dosage: Not specified (high-fructose diet for 15 weeks; metformin administered once daily for the last 6 weeks)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the effects of high-fructose diets in combination with different dietary fats on intestinal microbiota composition and metabolic function in rats.
results_summary: The study found that high-fructose diets combined with peanut oils (PO and HOPO) enhanced intestinal microbiota diversity compared to saturated fats, with HOPO showing better metabolic regulation (body weight and insulin sensitivity) than PO.
population_specificity: Sprague-Dawley (SD) rats fed a high-fat/high-fructose (HFF) diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the combined effects of fructose and common food preservatives on the development and progression of metabolic dysfunction-associated steatotic liver disease (MASLD).
results_summary: Fructose, particularly when combined with potassium sorbate, induced liver pathology (steatosis, inflammation, fibrosis), altered lipid profiles, disrupted gut microbiota, and increased pro-inflammatory responses. These effects were linked to transcriptional changes in genes involved in lipid metabolism, oxidative stress, and inflammation.
population_specificity: Human microbiota-associated mouse model.
interactions: Combined effects with potassium sorbate, sodium benzoate, and sodium nitrite were noted.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of Adipose-derived mesenchymal stem cells (ADMSCs) on metabolic disorders induced by a high fructose diet (HFrD) and explore the underlying molecular mechanisms.
results_summary: ADMSCs improved liver functions, reduced oxidative stress, enhanced gut microbiota activity, and increased adiponectin and IL10 levels. They also attenuated insulin resistance by upregulating IRS1 and downregulating SREBP-1 and Malat1.
population_specificity: Rats (animal study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of vitamin D3 supplementation (VDS), high-intensity interval training (HIIT), and their combination on the transcription factors and enzymes of the de novo lipogenesis (DNL) pathway in rats fed a high-fructose diet (HFrD).
results_summary: The study found that both HIIT and VDS significantly reduced markers of metabolic dysfunction (e.g., insulin, fasting blood glucose, liver triglycerides, and cholesterol) and intrahepatic lipid accumulation caused by HFrD. The combined intervention of HIIT and VDS yielded the most substantial improvements across all measured parameters.
population_specificity: Male Sprague‒Dawley rats
effective_dosage: 10% (w/v) fructose solution in tap water for the HFrD group; 10000 IU/kg/week VDS for the intervention group

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of isocaloric fructose restriction on adipose tissue distribution and serum adipokines in individuals with a BMI >28 kg/m².
results_summary: The study found that a fructose-restricted diet led to a favorable change in adipose tissue distribution (specifically a decrease in the VAT/SAT ratio in the intervention group) but did not significantly affect serum adipokine levels. No significant differences in visceral adipose tissue (VAT) were observed between groups.
population_specificity: Individuals with a BMI >28 kg/m² (n=44).
effective_dosage: Oral supplementation with fructose or glucose powder three times daily (exact dosage not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of fructose supplementation on inducing non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) in a rat model and assess the potential protective role of Saccharomyces boulardii.
results_summary: Fructose supplementation (35%) induced NAFLD in rats, characterized by increased lipid accumulation, oxidative stress, and elevated liver enzymes. Treatment with S. boulardii significantly reduced these adverse effects, improving lipid metabolism and oxidative stress markers.
population_specificity: Wistar rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether 6-gingerol (6-G) could alleviate fructose-induced hepatic steatosis by targeting stearoyl-CoA desaturase (SCD).
results_summary: 6-G significantly reduced hyperlipidemia and hepatic de novo lipogenesis (DNL) caused by high-fructose diets in rats, both in vivo and in vitro. It directly inhibited SCD activity without altering its expression, thereby reducing lipid accumulation.
population_specificity: Rats, HepG2 cells, and SCD1 knockout mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to elucidate the relationship between fructose utilization and pancreatic cancer progression.
results_summary: The study found that pancreatic cancer cells efficiently utilize fructose, exacerbating cancer proliferation by enhancing glycolysis and angiogenesis. Pharmacological blockade of fructose metabolism slowed cancer progression and enhanced anti-tumor effects when combined with anti-angiogenic agents.
population_specificity: Pancreatic cancer cells (in vitro or animal model, not specified for human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of systemic KHK inhibition versus hepatocyte-specific KHK knockdown on fructose metabolism and liver steatosis in mice.
results_summary: Both KHK siRNA and KHK inhibitor improved liver steatosis but through different mechanisms—KHK knockdown reduced de novo lipogenesis, while the inhibitor increased fatty acid oxidation. KHK knockdown prevented hepatic fructolysis and improved glucose tolerance, whereas the inhibitor partially reduced fructolysis but caused fructose-1 phosphate accumulation, leading to glycogen buildup and impaired glucose tolerance.
population_specificity: Mice on a high-fat diet (HFD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Fructose-1,6-bisphosphate (FBP) could counteract the hypotensive effects of L-kynurenine (KYN) in rats.
results_summary: FBP treatment reversed the KYN-induced decrease in mean and diastolic blood pressure and heart rate variability, suggesting a potential role in mitigating hypotension caused by inflammation. Molecular docking simulations indicated similar binding properties of KYN and FBP to the KCNQ4 channel.
population_specificity: Wistar rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antidiabetic effects of compounds 5b and 5f in a fructose-induced insulin resistance rat model, focusing on glucose homeostasis and lipid metabolism.
results_summary: Compounds 5b and 5f improved glucose uptake, glycogen content, and insulin sensitivity while reducing VLDL and triglyceride levels in fructose-induced insulin-resistant rats. They also demonstrated favorable pharmacokinetic profiles and binding affinity to PPAR-γ.
population_specificity: Fructose-induced insulin resistance rat model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to clinically evaluate the effects of 1,5-AF oral intake on mental stress, focusing on sleep, mood, and bowel issues.
results_summary: 1,5-AF significantly improved "sleepiness on rising" and "sleep length," reduced "Anger-Hostility," and showed a tendency to reduce "diarrhea or liquid stool."
population_specificity: Healthy volunteers aged 22-71 years (n = 24).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the mechanisms by which apical fructose utilization through glycolysis inhibits hypoxia-induced RIP-dependent necroptosis in colorectal cancer (CRC) cells.
results_summary: The study found that apical fructose prevents hypoxia-induced RIP-dependent necroptosis in CRC cells, preserves epithelial integrity, and upregulates glycolytic metabolites, suggesting a role in metabolic adaptation within the tumor microenvironment.
population_specificity: Three CRC cell lines (Caco-2, HT29, and T84) under normoxic and hypoxic conditions.
effective_dosage: Varying fructose concentrations (specific amounts not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the anti-oncogenic function of Fructose 1,6-bisphosphatase (FBP) and compare the structural properties of its isozymes (FBP1 and FBP2) in exerting anticancer effects.
results_summary: The study found that FBP acts as an anti-oncogenic protein by reducing glycolytic capacity and influencing oxidative metabolism, with FBP2 showing stronger interaction with the pro-oncogenic protein ALDOA compared to FBP1. Cancer cells exhibit reduced FBP levels and overexpress ALDOA, which may block FBP's anti-oncogenic activity.
population_specificity: Not specified (focus on cellular and molecular mechanisms, not human subjects).
study_duration: Not applicable (review study, not an intervention).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of a high-fructose diet on hepatic remodeling, energy metabolism, and endoplasmic reticulum stress in mice, and assess the potential benefits of LDT409 in mitigating these effects.
results_summary: The high-fructose diet induced insulin resistance and ER stress, increased liver steatosis, and upregulated pro-fibrogenic genes. LDT409 treatment reduced lipogenic factors, mitigated ER stress, and enhanced beta-oxidation, suggesting potential benefits for metabolic dysfunction-associated steatotic liver disease.
population_specificity: Male C57BL/6 mice
effective_dosage: 40 mg/kg of body weight (mixed with diet)
study_duration: 5 weeks (treatment phase after 10 weeks of dietary intervention)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of Fructose 1,6-bisphosphate aldolase (FBA) in oral cancer prognosis, disease progression, and response to radiotherapy.
results_summary: The study suggests FBA is a promising prognostic marker for oral cancer, with dysregulated metabolic pathways involving FBA potentially contributing to radiation resistance. It highlights the need for further exploration of FBA-targeted therapeutic strategies.
population_specificity: Oral cancer patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and validate a novel FBPase inhibitor (compound 45) for potential treatment of elevated fasting blood glucose in type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: Compound 45 showed increased inhibitory activity against FBPase (IC50, 2.08 μM) and demonstrated potent gluconeogenesis inhibition in mice, comparable to metformin, without inhibiting common human cytochrome P450 subtypes.
population_specificity: ICR mice (animal study).
interactions: None mentioned (no inhibition of human cytochrome P450 subtypes).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the mechanism by which maternal high fructose diet (HFD) induces retinal dysfunction in offspring and assess the potential of omega-3 PUFAs to reverse these effects.
results_summary: Maternal HFD led to early-onset retinal dysfunction in male offspring, marked by reduced b-wave amplitude and increased inflammatory markers (CD11b, p40phox, GFAP, NLPR3). Short-term omega-3 PUFA treatment reversed these changes.
population_specificity: Male rodent offspring exposed to maternal HFD during pregnancy and lactation.
effective_dosage: Not specified for fructose; omega-3 PUFAs administered for 2 weeks (from 2.5 to 3 months old).
study_duration: Maternal HFD during pregnancy and lactation; omega-3 PUFA intervention for 2 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of dietary supplementation of phlorizin on high-fat and high-fructose diet (HFFD)-induced cognitive dysfunction and evaluate the role of the microbiota-gut-brain axis.
results_summary: Phlorizin supplementation prevented cognitive dysfunction, improved synaptic plasticity, reduced neuroinflammation, and enhanced gut microbiota diversity in HFFD mice. The protective effects were linked to increased neurotransmitter expression and microbial metabolites like SCFA and BHB.
population_specificity: Mice fed a high-fat and high-fructose diet (HFFD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of Brazil nut and metformin on diabetic cardiomyopathy in fructose/STZ-induced type 2 diabetic rats and characterize bioactive compounds in Brazil nut extract.
results_summary: Fructose/STZ administration induced insulin resistance, hyperglycemia, and cardiac dysfunction, which were ameliorated by Brazil nut and metformin, with combined treatment showing superior effects.
population_specificity: Male albino Wistar rats with fructose/STZ-induced type 2 diabetes.
effective_dosage: Brazil nut extract (100 mg/kg, orally) and metformin (100 mg/kg, orally).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether chronic inhibition of the renin-angiotensin system (RAS) could restore blood pressure and improve cardiorenal function in rats fed a high fructose and high salt diet.
results_summary: The study found that high fructose and high salt diets elevated blood pressure and caused cardiac and renal damage in rats, which was improved by RAS inhibitors (enalapril or losartan). Functional improvements in cardiorenal parameters were noted, though some effects were sex-specific.
population_specificity: Male and female Sprague Dawley rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of Erythrina subumbrans extract (EES) on improving insulin resistance conditions induced by fructose in Wistar rats.
results_summary: EES significantly reduced weight gain, TNF-α levels, and FFA levels while increasing adiponectin levels and improving insulin resistance, comparable to metformin. The extract also promoted the formation of brown adipose tissue (BAT).
population_specificity: Adult male Wistar rats with fructose-induced insulin resistance.
effective_dosage: 100 mg/kg BW, 200 mg/kg BW, and 400 mg/kg BW of EES.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the effects and mechanisms of resistant starch (RS) in mitigating high-fructose corn syrup (HFCS)-induced colon tumorigenesis.
results_summary: RS suppressed HFCS-induced colon tumorigenesis by reshaping the microbial community, increasing intestinal SCFAs (especially butyrate), and downregulating glycolysis and CRC cell proliferation via HK2 suppression.
population_specificity: Azoxymethane/dextran sodium sulfate (AOM/DSS) and ApcMin/+ mice models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of a high-fructose diet (HFD) on hepatic encephalopathy in rats and assess the therapeutic potential of Sonchus maritimus-loaded niosomes (SmE-N) compared to metformin.
results_summary: The HFD group showed significant adverse effects, including behavioral changes, liver and brain tissue damage, oxidative stress, and altered enzyme levels. Treatment with SmE-N and metformin partially reversed these effects, with SmE-N demonstrating superior efficacy compared to metformin.
population_specificity: Male rats (n=24, divided into 4 groups of 6).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether fructose-1,6-bisphosphate (FDP) postconditioning could protect against myocardial ischemia-reperfusion injury in patients undergoing cardiac valve replacement surgery.
results_summary: FDP postconditioning significantly reduced markers of myocardial injury (e.g., CK-MB, cardiac troponin I) and improved spontaneous cardiac rhythm recovery compared to the control group, with statistically significant results (P < 0.001).
population_specificity: Patients undergoing elective mitral or aortic valve replacement surgery with extracorporeal circulation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of fructose-bisphosphate B (ALDOB) in glycolysis regulation and its potential as a therapeutic target in gastric cancer.
results_summary: The study found that ALDOB was significantly downregulated in gastric cancer tissues, acted as a tumor suppressor, inhibited proliferation and migration, delayed glycolysis in cancer cells, and increased sensitivity to antitumor drugs.
population_specificity: Gastric cancer patients and cell lines.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of a high-fructose diet on the jejunum of rats and assess whether THC could reverse these effects.
results_summary: Fructose consumption triggered inflammation, disrupted cell proliferation balance, and increased mucus secretion in the jejunum, while THC treatment suppressed inflammation and improved cell proliferation balance. Ultrastructural damage from fructose was partially reversed by THC.
population_specificity: Sprague-Dawley rats
effective_dosage: 10% fructose solution in drinking water (HFD group), 1.5 mg/kg/day THC (THC groups)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and evaluate a laser-activated biosensor for detecting D-fructose in biological fluids using Fructose dehydrogenase (FDH) for direct enzymatic bioelectrocatalysis.
results_summary: The study demonstrated that CO2 laser activation of carbon inks enabled direct electron transfer (DET) between FDH and the electrode surface, achieving sub-micromolar detection limits (0.24–0.47 μM) and high selectivity. The biosensors successfully measured D-fructose in synthetic and real biological fluids with good recoveries (93–112%) and continuous monitoring capability.
population_specificity: Synthetic and real biological fluids (e.g., cerebrospinal fluid)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of galantamine on autonomic dysfunction linked to early cardiometabolic dysfunction in offspring of fructose-overloaded rats.
results_summary: Fructose overload in rats led to decreased insulin tolerance, increased blood pressure, heart rate, and altered cardiovascular autonomic modulation. Galantamine treatment improved these parameters, restoring cardiovascular autonomic function and mitigating cardiometabolic dysfunction.
population_specificity: Offspring of Wistar rats exposed to fructose overload during gestation and lactation.
effective_dosage: 10% fructose in drinking water for parents; 5 mg/kg galantamine orally for offspring.
study_duration: Galantamine administered until offspring were 51 days old.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether postnatal fructose consumption potentiates the effects of prenatal dexamethasone exposure on synaptic plasticity, behavior, and cognition in adult male Wistar rats.
results_summary: Postnatal fructose consumption did not modify the effects of prenatal dexamethasone exposure, which included anxiolytic-like effects, increased exploratory behavior, and novelty preference. The study found no significant interaction between fructose and prenatal glucocorticoid exposure on the measured outcomes.
population_specificity: Adult male Wistar rat offspring exposed to prenatal dexamethasone.
study_duration: Postnatal fructose supplementation after weaning (exact duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of fructose supplementation and chronic stress on uterine contractile activity, morphology, and antioxidant enzyme activity in rats.
results_summary: Fructose supplementation altered uterine morphology, reduced response to oxytocin, and increased glutathione peroxidase activity. Combined with stress, it led to irregular estrous cycles and further impaired uterine responses.
population_specificity: Virgin Wistar rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine fructose's role and mechanism in colorectal cancer liver metastasis (CRLM).
results_summary: The study found that fructose absorbed by primary colorectal cancer accelerates CRLM, with KHK-A promoting metastasis via PKM2 phosphorylation, activating EMT and aerobic glycolysis. TEPP-46 treatment inhibited this pro-metastatic effect.
population_specificity: Colorectal cancer (CRC) and colorectal cancer liver metastasis (CRLM) models (in vitro and in vivo).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify a metabolic pathway activated in hereditary fructose intolerance (HFI) and explore potential therapeutic targets to mitigate fructose-induced metabolic dysregulation.
results_summary: The study found that fructose activates the purine degradation pathway via AMPD2 in aldolase B deficient mice, leading to metabolic dysregulation. Blocking AMPD2 improved metabolic outcomes and increased fructose tolerance without affecting F1P accumulation or hypoglycemia risk.
population_specificity: Aldolase B deficient mice (modeling hereditary fructose intolerance in humans).
effective_dosage: Very low amounts of fructose (specific dosage not quantified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of physiologically attainable levels of fructose on insulin sensitivity and branched-chain amino acid (BCAA) catabolism in skeletal muscle cells, both with and without insulin resistance.
results_summary: Fructose reduced peak glycolytic and mitochondrial metabolism but did not alter BCAA catabolic enzyme expression. However, it elevated extracellular BCAA levels in insulin-resistant cells, suggesting impaired BCAA utilization during insulin resistance.
population_specificity: C2C12 mouse myoblasts (in vitro skeletal muscle model)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether spirulina supplementation could improve NAFLD characteristics, intestinal microbiota, and pancreatic-renal lesions induced by a high-fructose diet in rats.
results_summary: The study found that a 10% spirulina-enriched diet maintained serum triglyceride levels, reduced liver fat, improved intestinal microbiota diversity, and lowered the Firmicutes/Bacteroidetes ratio compared to a high-fructose diet alone.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats weighing 200-250 g.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of magnoflorine in mitigating renal injury induced by high-fat and high-fructose diets in a CKD mouse model.
results_summary: The study found that magnoflorine treatment improved renal function indices and reduced histological damage in mice fed high-fat and high-fructose diets by promoting Parkin/PINK1-mediated mitophagy and inhibiting NLRP3 inflammasome activation.
population_specificity: CKD mouse model subjected to high-fat and high-fructose diets.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the sex-dependent effects of metformin on gut microbiota, intestinal tight junction proteins, and inflammation in high-fructose-induced metabolic syndrome in rats.
results_summary: High-fructose consumption induced metabolic syndrome and altered gut microbiota, while metformin treatment improved biochemical parameters, reduced inflammation, and modulated gut microbial composition in a sex-dependent manner.
population_specificity: Male and female rats with high-fructose-induced metabolic syndrome.
effective_dosage: 20% fructose solution in drinking water; metformin at 200 mg/kg once daily.
study_duration: 15 weeks (fructose), with metformin administered during the final 7 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the molecular mechanisms behind the negative effects of fructose intake using liver organoids as an in vitro model.
results_summary: Fructose-treated liver organoids showed increased selenoprotein p (Sepp1) gene expression and reduced DNA methylation in the Sepp1 region, consistent with findings in fructose-fed rats. No such effects were observed in two-dimensional cell models.
population_specificity: Liver organoids and hepatic tissues from rats.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the performance of a MgSnO3 catalyst for glucose isomerization to fructose, focusing on yield, selectivity, and regeneration methods.
results_summary: The MgSnO3 catalyst achieved a fructose equilibrium yield of 29.8% with over 90% selectivity under mild conditions and demonstrated successful regeneration via photoirradiation, avoiding energy-intensive calcination. The study highlighted the catalyst's acid-base interaction and photoregeneration mechanism for sustainable biomass conversion.
population_specificity: Not applicable (catalyst study, not human or animal subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether quercetin supplementation could improve insulin sensitivity in fructose-treated rats and assess the metabolic effects of fructose consumption.
results_summary: Quercetin supplementation normalized fructose intake, reduced plasma glucose and HOMA-IR index, and unexpectedly, fructose combined with methyl cellulose lowered uric acid and oxidative stress markers.
population_specificity: Rats treated with 10% fructose solution for 9 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether selenium (Se) could protect against kidney damage caused by high-fructose corn syrup (HFCS) by mitigating endoplasmic reticulum (ER) stress, oxidative stress, and apoptosis.
results_summary: The study found that HFCS caused kidney damage, increased oxidative stress, and upregulated ER stress markers, while selenium supplementation significantly reduced these adverse effects, improving histopathological outcomes and lowering oxidative and ER stress indicators.
population_specificity: Experimental animals (rats or mice, exact species not specified)

study_goal: The researchers were evaluating the effects of different feed additives (not fructose) on heifers.
results_summary: The abstract does not mention fructose or its effects, as the study focused on other additives like virginiamycin, monensin, tylosin, live yeast, sodium bicarbonate, and magnesium oxide.
population_specificity: Heifers (n = 40)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether fructose-modified CaBPs-Na2FDP@CaCl2 nanosheets could enhance selective anticancer bioactivity and osteoblast activity in osteosarcoma treatment.
results_summary: Fructose modification enabled targeted uptake by GLUT5-positive osteosarcoma cells, enhancing chemotherapeutic effects via ATP disturbance-mediated apoptosis, while degrading safely into non-toxic components (PO43-, Ca2+, fructose) in normal cells, promoting osteoblast differentiation.
population_specificity: GLUT5-positive 143B osteosarcoma cells and MC3T3-E1 pro-osteoblastic cells (in vitro); osteosarcoma models (in vivo).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compile information on the differential diagnosis of hereditary fructose intolerance to develop a diagnostic algorithm for early identification.
results_summary: Individuals with fructose intolerance may experience acute postprandial symptoms like hypoglycemia, vomiting, and abdominal distension, as well as chronic complications such as fatty liver and growth deficiency. The proposed diagnostic algorithm seeks to minimize these adverse effects.
population_specificity: Individuals with hereditary fructose intolerance (1 in 20,000 people).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the impact of rutin and vitamin A on glycation, oxidative stress, and inflammation in animals fed a high-fat high-fructose diet.
results_summary: The combination of rutin and vitamin A significantly reduced glycated products (HbA1c), oxidative markers (MDA, CAT, GPx), and inflammatory cytokines (IL-6, IL-8, NF-κB) in rats on a high-fructose high-fat diet. The treatment also prevented cellular damage and showed strong molecular docking affinity for key biomolecules.
population_specificity: 30 rats divided into six groups (n = 5 per group).
effective_dosage: High-fructose high-fat diet (specific fructose dosage not detailed); rutin (100 mg/kg), vitamin A (43 IU/kg), and metformin (120 mg/kg) were administered.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the prevalence of fructose intolerance in children with abdominal pain and assess the effectiveness of dietary interventions.
results_summary: The study found that 70% of pediatric patients tested positive for fructose intolerance, with 67.5% experiencing symptoms during testing. Dietary changes, including low-FODMAP and other diets, improved symptoms in 43 patients.
population_specificity: Pediatric patients (under 20 years old) presenting with abdominal pain, diarrhea, or vomiting and negative GI evaluation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether fructose could mitigate the detrimental effects of titanium dioxide nanoparticles (TiO2 NPs) on murine oocyte development and oxidative stress markers.
results_summary: Fructose significantly alleviated the harmful effects of TiO2 NPs, improving oxidative and antioxidant biomarkers, reducing apoptotic gene expression, and enhancing oocyte development. It also mitigated TiO2 NP-induced alterations in oocyte cell surfaces.
population_specificity: Sexually mature female mice (8-12 weeks old, ~25 g body weight).
effective_dosage: 2.75 mM/ml, administered intraperitoneally for 5 consecutive days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the impact of excessive fructose consumption on diabetic kidney disease (DKD) progression, focusing on underlying mechanisms of renal damage.
